pros: The colleagues are mostly friendly and helpful. All campuses are near transport links and the food on said campuses is nice.
cons: The management only ever pay lip service to what your demands, whether as an individual or a group. They will work you like a dog for under the going rate of pay for your grade. They won't trust you to do your job on your own and won't adequately train you either.

pros: - I thought KCL, for the most part, was very good because it had a broad range of opportunities, and the ability to engage with high-level professors/academics. - You can get involved in delivering campus tours, writing articles/blog posts, contribute to and monitor Q&A sessions, get involved in KCL-wide research projects (e.g. in sustainability, academic processes, health, etc), research projects in science departments, ... - Great shared facilities (bookable open collaborative spaces & closed isolated spaces; scientific equipment for cognitive neuroscience, psychiatry, engineering, chemistry, medicine; labs; museum object exhibits; books; e-resources, e-journals publications, all hardware & software suites for data analyses (e.g. in human sciences, social sciences studies, etc), available for registered staff/students. - I also did my MSc there.
cons: - Even as a worker there, further specific duties remain competitive/selective, for which you may not have much control over, and unfortunately you will not get everything that you want and sign up for. Sometimes, you will be assigned to things they decide for you (which is fine but I suppose you have to take the initiative to make the most out of that opportunity). - Feedback on applications/work/assignments, like coursework/exams, is not automatically given, it has to be proactively requested much of the time, and even then they may not give very at-length specific/detailed constructive feedback. It's a shame because that is the main purpose of the process of work experience and experiential learning - to be able to better yourself as soon as possible for the next thing/event. (I suppose staff there have very limited time & resources to be able to provide those, and have to comply to regulations - just like most other universities/institutions/organisations I suppose ...).

review_title: Contract to contract with no opportunity for career progression
pros: - Premier academic institution producing some of the best research in the world which is exciting to contribute to. - Everyone is interested and passionate about what they do. - All KCL employees receive 27 days of annual leave a year + concessionary days between Christmas and New Years. - Pay is decent with £4000 London Weighting Allowance - Flexible work policy means high degree of flexibility contingent on arrangements made with line manager
cons: - Like all UK universities, research labour has been casualised meaning there is little job security as you hop from fixed-term contract to the next. This is especially problematic if you need a visa. - Many staff are hired through King's Talent Bank which further increases instability. - The grades are highly inflexible. One cannot be hired at grade 5 without a master's degree and cannot advance to grade 6 without a PhD, meaning there is no opportunity for career progression without further (expensive) education. - Similarly, there is no opportunity for pay rises based on performance. You automatically advance one spine point within your grade on 1 August to earn a few hundred pounds more a year.

pros: Highly dependent on your team. In the good ones, there's a strong focus on learning and development, positive staff cultures and flexibility. Minimum time in the office is 5 days per month but some teams require more. Job roles are becoming more harmonised which is making it easier to move across teams. Lots of opportunity for promotion. Often opportunities arise to work with colleagues in different areas of the university, academics, researchers, students and professional services. There can be a really positive community feel amongst staff.
cons: Shares many of the problems of old bureaucratic organisations, can be slow to change, decision making is slow, strong sense of risk aversion and senior leadership team sometimes shy away from transparency and consultation. New leadership team means changing strategies and power dynamics which has led to quite a bit of uncertainty, ambiguity and a culture where there's a lack of trust.

pros:
Sometimes free food on your break which is good because you can't afford to buy your own food with the salary they give you every month

You will meet alot of people and contacts in this role if you socialise well since it is a university which means you'll be able to progress to better opportunities quickly if you use it to your advantage 

The pension is not bad but you'll only be earning around £1400s net or £1500s if you choose to go without a pension I think it's 6% of your monthly salary and the employer (King's College London) contributes 19%

Holidays I think are 27 days and you get Christmas week and New Year's off
cons:
You get £21712 a year with the London Allowance (£3500) but your base rate isn't calculated from £21712 but from £18212 which is roughly £10 an hour so when you do overtime you get around £15 per hour but they will try to cut your overtime hours on your rota as much as possible

In the interview I was promised overtime (1.5x) and Sunday rate (2x) but in the contract they said that you're contracted to work 5 out of the 7 days a week so they will scatter your days off around the weekdays to avoid you getting your Sunday rate (2x) and yes you will have to work week ends on short notice 

There is an "us" vs. "them" toxic environment and makes navigating this role extremely uneasy especially when you just want to work and be unbiased

In the job description it doesn't say formal dining but they will try to make you do formal dining and there is alot of micro-managing despite this role being extremely easy 

I'm an active person and physically fit but you will be on your feet almost all the 7 hours on the shift running around different buildings and you will get tired 

The rota doesn't get finalised until the Friday before the start of the week and you will be told to do weekends without being asked. Virtually no control of the rota if you ask for a reasonable arrangement the manager will think they're doing this as a favour to you - there's also weeks when you have a late shift and the following day is an early shift which affects your sleep especially if you live far.

You will be treated like you're a young child if you don't wear your uniform correctly in a humiliating manner 

Pretentious 3-month and 6-month "probationary performance reviews" more to give the managers a platform to formally bully you on paper and on the record. If you manage to stay this long on this role don't be fooled this isn't a meeting to discuss your progress but for them to assess how well you perform based on biased allegations from other supervisors.

They'll ask to give your number and social media so they can contact you 24/7 on when you're available to do shifts because the team is under-staffed

pros:
- They have some nice offices in central London
- They can invest big money into projects - when they want to
- It's prestigious as a university, and invests a lot in teaching
- It's fine if you work here a short while; get some experience in a huge, self-obsessed organisation, and then you can take those skills elsewhere. In a relatively short time period, you're unlikely to notice or be bothered by endemic problems. I'd say 1-2 years here, max.
cons:
Where to start?
- Incredible amounts of bureaucracy - it's a bureaucracy beast
- Lots of politics - the right people are often not in the right jobs, not held to account with poor performance management. Issues end up long-standing and not addressed because management and senior leadership avoid uncomfortable conversations
- Deep-seated hyporcrisy; on the one hand they will talk about the importance of well-being, make a fuss, put on online meditation and make a show of looking after staff. They also love to harp on about the students. The truth is the absolute priority is the King's reputation. Risk of "reputational damage" dominates everything - it's an obsession. They will put this above everything, including what is in the best interests of students, and definitely well above what is in the best interests of staff. Indeed staff and their wellbeing, career progression and general working experience is not a priority. It's all focused on how anything makes them look in the media.
- Development and progression is stunted; sometimes, there are toxic teams where development is prevented - making is very hard to progress upwards within the organisation. King's will quicker hire an external candidate - who will be loyal and bendable to the hiring manager's whims, than an internal candidate who has worked hard, proven themselves and build relationships and a good reputation. Sadly, there are a lot insecure people in leadership positions who seem to fear promoting people who may know more about ground-level operations that they do.

review_title: As universities go, KCL is a good employer overall in my experience
job_title: Senior Research Fellow in London, England
pros: It is brilliant to be part of a world leading research community. I'm very interested in the work that I do and I believe it has value for society more broadly. The people I work with are great. I believe KCL overall is a good employer and has been supportive to employees during the COVID crisis.
cons: I think that your experience of working here depends very much on your department and team. As this is such a huge institution, experiences can vary greatly. The general 'cons' of working in academia and in a large institution apply here too. Due to the size of the organisation and hierarchical structure, processes are very slow and cumbersome. It is often difficult to find the information you need as an employee due to the structure of the information online and the number of people that work here with different responsibilities that are not always immediately clear. I have heard that the working culture in some departments in terms of long hours and presenteeism is a problem, luckily this does not apply to me personally. Like most universities, there is a big problem with diversity and inclusion particularly in terms of the representation of women, ethnic minorities and LGBTQ people in senior roles, but I believe KCL is committed to addressing this.

job_title: Human Resources Professional in London, England
pros: paid on time, made a couple of life long friends
cons:
Middle management really believe they have all the power in the world meanwhile they are upper management puppets. They believe they hold top secret information about how the cogs turn in the office but we all know how things work:
1.Favoured white people get jobs without interview but they make others interview for the role. Other white males get a role without jobs being advertised.
2. There is nepotism.com in the whole HR Dep. Boyfriends and girlfriends, sisters and their friends all rise up together.
3. Upper management is white and so is middle management
4. Any POC in management renounced their origins to fit in with white people.
5. It doesn't matter how many times you interview or if you have a masters/ cipd and great experience. If "they" don't like you, you won't get the job. 
6. Long hours, there is an unspoken expectation to work long hours to get work done. Lot of us work weekends without pay or time off in lieu.
7. Disregard to mental wellbeing especially after lockdown.
8. POC do not get opportunities despite being the ones who have the most experience and qualifications.
9. Middle management bully the people who ask questions or the ones who provide good ideas. 
10. When individuals raise bullying concerns, upper manager say they don't see the problem and in future to speak with the line manager (who is the person who bullies or belittles a lot of people).
11.It is so bad here that we can count on one hand the good people (out of 90 +)

Other than that if you want to progress, you are better off leaving and and developing yourself. KCL is a dead end if you are not favoured.
There are also managers who have narrow minds regarding gender roles. Some have said that they believe women belong in the kitchen and are only on Earth to make kids for us.

review_title: Worst experience of my working life to date
pros: Despite the negatives below, I do take pride in working for King's - its reputation is very good.
cons:
I find the overall culture to be really rather toxic.  I think it's culturally a very mixed bag here, though, because of the degree of fragmentation between different areas of the university.  This means you really don't know what you will get.  Accounts from other employees suggest a brilliant working environment in some areas.  Where I am, this is simply not the case.  Progress and recognition are not a consideration, it's a thankless job and I wonder why I bother.

Years of underinvestment and sitting on the laurels of a good reputation now mean that an immense degree of change is happening all at the same time, and I do not have any confidence that it will be effectively managed.

If this institution makes it through the turbulent times we are in due to Brexit, political forces, socioeconomic dynamics and the like, it will be more by luck than judgment.


There is a distinct air of arrogance at the senior management level.  It seems like they consider that the rules do not apply to them.  They do not hold management  accountable for their actions, and management do not, essentially, manage.

review_title: Two tracks, academic and others, working in very different environments - great for academics, others steer clear
pros:
Excellent academic reputation with established recognition on a worldwide scale - as evidenced by recent move to top 20 of world rankings in one survey.
Opportunities for academic collaboration across numerous research areas
Central London location provides easy access to other excellent academic, political, cultural and business institutions.
Great place for any academic to work.
cons:
Lack of investment in IT services leaves it well behind some of its Russell Group competitors
Dominant role of the medical school, leaves other areas as poor relations
Severe lack of strategic planning from all senior management - again due to individuals protecting their areas rather than seeing organisation as a whole.
Poor senior management across the professional services functions (IT, HR, Estates etc) - more interested in keeping their heads down and defending their patch than in providing the  collaborative support needed to help drive the university forward.
Very resistant to change and therefore limited availability for interesting and challenging work for professional services staff.

review_title: PhD student, funded with a UKRC studentship
pros:
Prestigious University, in an academically vibrant city. 
The cost of London is very high. 
But as there are a lot of important Universities in London, there is the opportunity to interact with a lot of researchers. 
My UKRC studentship provided me enough to get by with my living expenses.
cons:
The cost of London is very high, and even with a UKRC studentship it is difficult to find an affordable accomodation (a small studio flat is just out of reach for example). 
King's College London can be a very dispersive and bureaucraic university. Funding can finish before the actual PhD degree does (writing-up period). Also, the university seems to be putting all PhD in a hot desking arrangment, separating PhDs from the rest of the research community.

pros: Central London location. Also some opportunities to speak with interesting people now and then when you deal with them.
cons:
No training provided whatsoever for new staff. I started on the first day of Fresher's week and had to learn on the go without any form of coaching beyond a couple of print-outs.

Verbally abusive and awkward management. Was told at one point that asking questions was not allowed, what kind of policy is this?  

Lower ranking staff members looked down on by some in more senior management.

However, the worst was the complete and utter disorganisation. In my three months at King's I witnessed the following in one department: 

1: An American student admitted in error and told on the door she could not enroll in her course
2: Two students kicked off their course as they had not been told they had failed the previous year
3: An exam scheduled in a room with no tables/desks.
4: Serious errors in exam papers.  
5: Various breaches of the data protection act (for example, the loss of data from study into the relationship between race and academic attainment amongst children). 

Ultimately this all made for a very toxic working environment. Avoid at all costs.

pros: A handful of nice people
cons:
An exceptionally high staff turnover, higher than any I've known, and absolutely nothing done to address this. Ridiculously high workload, and inadequate support for it. 

Everyone knows the Mental Health studies course is a disaster to work on, with a senior academic on that course being extremely hostile. What is done about it? Nothing. See the pattern here?

Toxicity defines the culture. People have walked out, gone off work for weeks with stress, filed complaints against management, fled to other departments and nothing changes.

Don't bother considering this place, it will take years to change.

review_title: great opportunities for personal and professional development
pros: King's college is not only a university with a great reputation in  teaching and research but a company that provides excellent tools for personal and professional development and an outstanding career service that can help with career change, promotions, CV review service.
cons: As in any other university progression from pos-doc level to lecturer is hard and a mentoring scheme has been set up only very recently. Moreover the working environment can vary within departments and teams. King's is doing  a lot to retain women in science, by organizing events, training, mentoring schemes, but unfortunately you can still hear very inappropriate and sexist comments in some departments.

pros: A strong academic base with experts in many fields and world-leaders in some.  Teaching and research are treated as equally important.
cons: Led by an obscenely overpaid clown, this once academically first-rate university  is being suffocated by tier upon tier of administrators, the numbers of which will soon surpass those of the academic staff, and whose dictats are dumped on the revenue-earning members of the College in ever-increasing blizzards.  A spectacularly absurd and wasteful managerial exercise was the recent attempt to 'rebrand' the College as 'King's London'.  Worse, this was followed by brazen case of mismanagement - a directive to sack large numbers of teaching and research staff on the basis of spurious and inappropriate 'performance metrics', while hiring even more managers - including PR wonks to spin the exercise. The mis-administrators of KCL have either lost sight of what a university is for, or never knew in the first place.

job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in London, England
pros: Multicultural environment as with most Universities. A place to collaborate and meet some very friendly, kind and considerate people. The best staff are not really there for the money but perhaps job security or to achieve some goals in life.
cons:
The university business is essentially to lure as many students into a life of debt, pay big money for big players, invest in lucrative markets e.g. drugs and pharmaceuticals, engage in the soft war whilst spreading secular culture to displaced peoples. All the while remaining politically correct and internally gagging the dissenting voices through non disclosure.
For many employees here there is no real chance of a pay increase or promotion. Only personal development reviews that are an essential waste of time. Then there are the one dimentional, selfish, egocentric bullies. Since ex News International staff wafted in, an uncanny form of nepotism has gripped IT. An old boys club of sly foul mouthed bosses whose basic instinct is to respond to the crack of the whip whilst protecting number 1. Did I mention the gossip, spying, peering over employees shoulder, deskilling, ridiculing, ostracising?

review_title: Would sooner jump off a cliff than go back there again
job_title: Non-Academic Staff Member (Would Prefer Not to BE More Specific) in London, England
pros: Erm, there were few. They paid your wages on time? Does that even count? Perhaps other departments were better...
cons:
Bullying by managers of junior staff was entirely tolerated. I, and several others, left our roles at King's because we simply couldn't take it any more. I used to get home and cry on a regular basis, and ended up on anti-depressants because of it. A friend from another department who regularly visited my own later described my department as having an all-pervading sense of misery. Senior management were either so incompetent they couldn't recognise what was going on, or didn't care, but either way nothing was ever done. I lasted almost a year, and felt a great sense of relief when I finally left. 

Other disadvantages: 
Low London weighting - the lowest of any London universities 
Five campuses across the capital. Staff were expected to travel between campuses, but weren't allowed to claim the money back on expenses. 
Ridiculous workload 
Poor work/life balance

review_title: Awful place to work due to bad culture and values
pros: The reputation for your CV can sound impressive and help with future career prospects.
cons: The management is terrible. They do not care about their employees, act as if they do by making their professional staff fill out surveys every week about how they find their work, and what they can do to improve your day to day work. However, they will not act on feedback to help you when an issue arises so its very deceptive. The Marketing team, as JCMB is awful. There is a particular type of people who work here. The culture is far from friendly, it is extremely corporate and social people will find it tedious to work in this environment, particularly if you are fairly young.

review_title: Relaxed corporate culture, but 'boy's club' - as a female employee, don't expect career progress
pros: Russell group university, has improved in rakings recently. Relaxed corporate climate, collaborative leadership style overall. Overall good relations between professional services and academics. Nice campus locations, work-life-balance ok. Salaries average for HEI.
cons: Experienced gender bias in career progression and promotions. Even when you have an outstanding performance, as a female manager, you will have to go through formal and competitive recruitment for a career progression. At the same time, male counterparties in the same team were promoted without going through any hassle.

review_title: HR department lets the entire university down
pros: World leading PIs, supportive colleagues. Good location though an eyesore standing next to the shard
cons: The worst HR department ever particularly for foreign employees. I cannot warn all foreigners enough. They messed up my visa process and I was forced into a 12 month cooling off period destroying any chance of having a job anywhere in the UK for  12 months due to their lack of understanding of how foreign employment works. This resulted in me being forced into unemployment for 6 ,on the and financially damaged. No compensation or even an apology from HR. So much so that they refuse to acknowledge their mistake. All foreign employees particularly postdocs BEWARE. This HR does not believe in the existence of human beings

pros:
There were some pleasant staff there, who tried to make a difference and supported others when things got rough.

Some programmes were better than others.
cons:
There were way too many staff leaving their positions after a short amount of time. It made people feel like their jobs were never safe, and took down the mood. It was so bad for continuity too.

There was a lot of really nasty treatment of staff in the form of sacking temps with no notice, and critical comments behind a person's back was the norm. I also saw a permanent member of staff get pushed out the door unfairly. There was no real training, probably because there was just nowhere to fit it in, and in the end I was relieved to be out of there.

pros:
Great place to work. High level of autonomy. Senior managers are very positive and supportive. Encourages a "can do attitude". Good work is acknowledged. Very, very good work-life balance - best I have experienced. Opportunities for working in cross-cutting initiatives. 
The culture is positive, open and forward looking.
Cultural bureaucracy that might be present in other very large public sector organisations is low.
Finally, this is all evidenced by the significant number of King's staff who "return" and some to lower grades.
cons: Salary scaling for professional grades are lower than other central London universities. Many of the professional services roles are fixed term, therefore a level of uncertainty is inherent.

job_title: Clinical Trial Manager in London, England
pros:
Management is supportive and encourages professional development. 
Excellent work life balance.  
Management focus on work output rather than bums on seats, which makes the employee feel trusted and they work harder
cons:
Communication about processes/changes could be improved as it is not as efficient as it could be.  This could be due the complex set-up of the organisation and it's partners. 
Each department has it's own way of working, which can make streamlining of processes a bit challenging.

pros:
Higher end university (though it tends to trade on its reputation rather than worrying about maintaining it).
Relaxed working environment (mostly but see management comments).
Historic reputation.
Certain specialist subjects highly rated.
Decent office space if you don't mind open plan.
cons:
Central computing facilities poor compared to other top end universities eg you cannot assume your desktop will be gigabit connected.
Management is top heavy and ineffective.
Wages not as good as some other colleges in London.
Not much chance of career progression except by changing jobs either within or without the college.

review_title: Resistance to change, lack of accountability
pros: Like most public sector jobs, particularly at professional services management level, the hours are reasonable for the pay and the pension scheme is pretty decent. Stress levels are low.
cons: There is a real culture of resistance to change and you're often having to do other people's jobs because they either take too long to do them or just don't do them. Also, I'm not sure I've ever worked somewhere where employees and their bosses will ignore emails and phone calls indefinitely because the question you're asking them is too difficult to answer. Nobody is held responsible when things go wrong. Poor working ethic seems to be rewarded with promotions or secondments.

pros: Really nice place to work. I was in one of the labs so I mainly dealt with the experiments and laboratory-related things. Every team is different in a way (probably because of the head of the team), and they all have their own inner culture.
cons: Ridiculously difficult to reach people. If you phone up the University and need to talk to guy A, they will pass you on to guy B, who will pass you on to guy C, and department X and whatnot. In the end, to get a simple answer out of them usually took a couple of hours, nobody wants to take responsibility for anything.

pros: Great people to work with, variety of cultures and backgrounds mean that I was learning new things constantly. The role involved a lot of in-person interactions with prospective students, giving tours of campus and answering questions online. Definitely given an opportunity to grow your soft skills.
cons: Sometimes the online interactions with prospective students can be on several platforms, which makes communications slightly more difficult. The actual events tend to be in a non-uniform basis (sometimes you'll be doing tours, the next minute you could be sitting completing admin work), which can be good for some as it provides a rotation of jobs, but perhaps a little hectic at some points.

pros: A high-ranking university for students over a number of campuses.
cons:
For 'staff' such as myself over several years, 'things' tend to 'deteriorate' over time, rather than improve. I had witnessed several colleagues rather badly 'manoeuvred out', only to have the same thing happen to myself - where I apparently became 'over-qualified' and 'too expensive' after 9 years.
Basically experience and skills do not necessarily ensure job security.

pros: I have done both my Biomedical Sciences BSc and MSc at King's College London and I am extremely happy with my experience. The staff is really friendly and helpful but most importantly I feel that the level of education is on a world class level. Many labs are publishing papers in top journals such as the cell or jbc.
cons: I really cannot think of any cons. It was a really good university experience and the only disadvantage of which comes to my mind is the cost of living in London, which in fact is increasing on a yearly basis.

pros:
1. Location of campuses are easy to get to
2. Due to high turnover and constant temp staff you get to know some lovely people
3. If you work for a niche specialist research centre tucked away within one of the smaller campuses or a really dedicated old-school Professor or Department Manager than it can be great 
4. Apart from a few Open Evenings or during busy times around examinations I usually finished work at 5pm
cons:
1. Very poor career progression - King's operates on a 'time served' versus performance progression. Thus you are more likely to stay or progress if you have been in the Department longer regardless if you are actually good at your job or not
2. Incredibly slow - King's is too big and too haphazard with their approach to communication across the various Faculties, Schools and Campuses 
3. Your line manager might not even work in the same campus or department as you
4. The job is over-sold including development opportunities. Training is often in the form of an online video or is only offered once a year with only 30 places available to thousands of staff. 
5. Highly toxic environment with rapid turnover. Some Departments are worse than others 
6. I had a permenant contract but I found that the temps worked harder and took their job more seriously than most of the other permanent staff members who did the bare minimum required. 
7. They don't value any sort of initiative or meaningful change
8. Admin Assistants and Course Administrators are treated like second class citizens. The way that some of the senior academics spoke to their admin staff was shocking. If an academic fails to turn up on time for a lecture or is 4 weeks late returning grade marks or has an unsuccessful research grant bid - somehow the admin staff will be scapegoated.

pros: Good experience teaching overall. The facilities are workable and the student body is generally engaged. There seems to be a rapprochement between different schools which is good to see.
cons:
wage was low compared to LSE and UCL

no office space for the TAs meaning feedback had to be given in public areas without privacy which made some of the less confident students feedback sessions harder to complete.

pros: Lovely and clever colleagues, work-life balance, great central location. Great short-term contract opportunities.
cons: So much bureaucracy. Haven't figured out how to balance independence of Schools/Departments with central services. This was particularly apparent for support services. Academic staff were high quality, but not at all business-minded.

job_title: International Student Ambassador in London, England
pros: An opportunity to improve communication skills; pay in accordance with London Living Wage; friendly staff; gives a chance to tell everyone about your experiences at KCL; occasional work for longer hours with more responsibilities
cons: The work opportunities are not schedule-fixed; you will be given work on "first come-first serve" basis; there is little assistance with your NINO application, in case you need to apply for one

pros: I was always being offered the opportunity to progress through additional training, attending lectures and seminars from world renown psychologist such as Michael Rutter. Nice team environment, everyone works together.
cons: As I had just graduated from University, at times it could feel like the senior management underestimated my work capability.

pros: Good central London location, giving flexibility about where to live.  Institutional reputation helps to open some doors.  Many of the staff are pleasant.
cons: Some teams have high staff turnover, losing administrative know how - can lose a lot of time getting basic tasks done.  Plan to move to shared offices for academic staff causing disquiet.

review_title: Good but limited to part time
pros:
King's College is a good institution to work for. I worked in the Library division where everything is really well organised and the team is very supportive and friendly.
There are frequent opportunities to apply for internal position and to grow within the company.
I started to work here on a temporary basis. After few months I applied for an internal position and I became permanent.
cons: They offer only few full time positions, so most of the people working in the libraries are working on a part time basis.

review_title: Researcher as PhD student in Biomedical Engineering and Imaging Sciences
pros: The employment at King's College London as a PhD researcher involves flexible hours. The main office is located in London, right in front of the Big Ben, which is a great and central location. The research group has multi-disciplinary research interests.
cons: Supervisors and colleagues at King's College London are perhaps overzealous in everything they do. While this is a pro in terms of quality of the research they carry out, this is counterproductive in terms of times required to fulfill every assignment.

pros:
- Friendly and supportive colleagues
- Engaged students
- Good holiday and pension
- Some excellent training courses
cons:
- Not sure I met one person who was happy working there in whole time I was!
- Unrealistically high workloads for uncompetitive pay due to chronic understaffing and lack of forward planning about staff numbers.
- Poor support for staff mental health and wellbeing.
- Many systems not fit for purpose.

review_title: Friendly and supportive place to work
pros:
- Nice people, relaxed atmosphere
- Decent pay
- Reasonably sympathetic management who care about development of their staff and good training opportunities
- Wide range of roles available
cons:
- Bureaucratic at times (but then what large organisation isn't?)
- Some teething problems moving from a traditional university into the "education marketplace" (but this is a general challenge in the whole HE sector)

job_title: Employer Engagement Officer in London, England
pros:
Flexible working hours. 
Hard-working, experienced and dedicated team. 
Friendly and relaxed working environment. 
Good management who looks after employees and supports them while building trust for a long-lasting professional relationship.
cons:
Some members of staff who have been in the department the longest seem to have lost interest in the work which affects the quality of service delivered to the wider team. 
Some heads of teams seem disconnected with the staff due to lack of contact caused by large amount of responsibilities.

review_title: Avoid if looking at fundraising roles and opportunities
job_title: Fundraising & Supporter Development in London, England
pros:
- Some good and intelligent colleagues
- Great location for office 
- Some very strong and worthwhile causes to raise funds for e.g. Evelina, Cancer Centre
cons:
- Awful management, bullying, toxic culture, which resulted in silence within office most days. Other days, teams talking amongst themselves could result in complaints
- Lack of support for new staff. Very much a focus on 'proving yourself' before being trusted or managed without constant supervision or being belittled
- Senior management seemingly very friendly with one another, particularly directors. No accountability for poor working practices, turnover and staff wellbeing
- Fairly poor and unclear messaging relating to fundraising successes and achievements. Donors not communicated with honestly

job_title: Human Resource Management in London, England
pros: It took about 4 weeks, It is was relaxing experience. If you are qualified and confident enough with adequate knowledge and information in your field, you should find the experience good. They will ask direct question related to the job descriptions and specification which you should be aware of. Very nice and cool environment for work.
cons: Very busy and challenging, which I don't think it is a really real Cons. However, the turn over seems to be high a little bit.

pros: Intelligent committed academics, good patient access, friendly atmosphere. Some campuses are well located, others less so. Good food options for staff.
cons: Appalling senior management, perennial threat of redundancy, hugely bloated and interfering management that seems to get bigger every day. Management does not trust staff and so imposes huge top-down bureaucracy. Procedures are inefficient and leadership weak. Promotion is non-existent unless you have a huge amount of grants.

pros: Work is okay. It is good to get teaching experience. You can learn things by teaching them. Generally nice people to work with.
cons:
Commuting into central London to deliver a 1 hour seminar wastes a lot of time. 
Not always matched to courses that are most appropriate. 
General feeling of being 'cheap labour' rather than getting the best Phd experience or giving the best learning experience for undergraduates. Degree Farm, not a pillar of learning.

pros: Competitive top-notch research environment and facilities.  Some friendly staff.
cons:
Only one year contracts specially for woman so they can easily get rid of you if you say go on Maternity Leave. 
Low ethics.  If you say go on Maternity Leave, other members of staff are encourage to take your work of years and take credits for it.

review_title: Full-time EAP Tutor in the English Language Centre
pros: I have worked with excellent colleagues and students at the ELC. There are loads of opportunities for professional development within the department and university.
cons: The workload is high and in much of the year taking leave is very difficult. Unlike most academic positions, this position requires that tutors be on campus from 9:00-5:00.

review_title: Not impressed IT Data Solutions Analyst
job_title: IT Solutions Analyst in London, England
pros:
1. They had doors allowing you to enter their buildings and rooms.

2. You get paid.

3. They had windows in their offices', albeit they were old.
cons:
Having worked in the Data Solutions team within the IT department on a fixed-term contract, it was, on balance a more negative than positive experience. It is worth fleshing out why this is the case.


1. When my contract ended and I requested a referee for my new job, a former colleague refused, alleging he had no time for this. This was roundly inconsistent with him not only being a referee for at least one other former colleague, but also writing several recommendations for him on business-oriented websites! It is more likely than not he did have time but bizarrely acted improperly with his mendacity.

2. About a year before my contract expired, one in charge of data solutions promised the year before he would furnish lots of notice should my contract not be extended. However, I was appalled that he gave just over two months notice period despite admitting that he was cognisant MONTHS before that my contract wouldn't be extended or made permanent! This made me feel misled, undervalued and upset, wherefore I was left battling to find work to avoid the mortification and difficulties of unemployment, during the impending Brexit vote - a difficult economic period that saw employers put the brakes on hiring while consumer and business confidence was dampening. I was trapped in unemployment for NEARLY A YEAR,  consequently impairing my economic situation, escalating family and personal worries, producing an IRREVOCABLE dark hole in my career history which damaged my reputation among employers and agencies to thereby make me less employable, and making me feel stupid, especially given he KNEW the probability of securing employment would've been higher had sufficient notice been given.  He had no decency to even apologise for his breech of promise.  Also, HR's policy said employees are to be notified 6 months in advance if contracts would not be extended. However, they failed to abide by this instead giving me a few months notice! Yet, they want employees to carefully adhere to policies, which is pure inconsistency.


3. He secretly told a colleague he did an illegality whereafter making this easy to detect to the team! How flippant and heedless for him to plough ahead with this! Action was taken against him, which hopefully made it less likely this will be repeated.


4. It was blindingly puzzling and unbecoming that my past manager infracted license agreements after admitting this to the team in such a heedless, imprudent manner! How on earth is it sensible to disclose something like that, especially so casually and nonchalantly, rather than putting things right?


5. I was very surprised he did not delegate work for nearly two months when I first joined the team! Instead, he put me on a training course, despite the fact I didn't need it. This gave me the inkling I was not needed in the team, didn't deserve to be paid plus it decelerated the pace of gaining experience in real-world project and the sector. What was bizarre was that a colleague didn't need the training he was placed on to enjoy professional development, as he had decades of experience and was closer to the end of his career than beginning! By contrast, I required this, but instead was put on courses which did not expand my professional competencies vis-a-vis to what I expected.


6. Meetings led by the one in charge of data-related solutions almost always overshot, sometimes taking half an hour longer than scheduled! Furthermore, the manager would sometimes socialise with colleagues, talking about housing, pensions, etc. despite the deadlines we had, ergo,the amount of time lost down to such mediocre  timekeeping was disappointing and counterproductive. Also, I would be sometimes interrupted when speaking in meetings, which I found impertinent.


7. I was disappointed the one managing data-related solutions, more often than not, assigned me the most boring and simplest work despite knowing my prowess and zeal to aim higher. I felt he had little confidence in me for no warranted reason, which explains why he gave me such work which was frankly, child's-play. It was hardly contributive to the department, and certainly less comprehensive than what the job specification said.


8. I never really felt part of the team as everyone else would speak to one another and just ignore me. I felt isolated especially during meetings when sometimes, no-one would even look at me!


9. On the floor wherein I worked, it was almost always chilly as they had no sense in fixing the heaters! It was because of this that a colleague suggested I leave the country and emigrate to a warmer one! How disrespectful!


10. Within the office I worked in, people spoke too much especially about silly, irrelevant matters i.e. sex, hobbies, etc. and didn't carry out more work than what could've been done despite time constraints for deliverables. I believe the culture should be more formal to consistently achieve the same results and make effective utilisation of time, something which cannot be regained once lost.


For these reasons, especially the first few enumerated, overall, I regret not leaving King's a lot sooner than I did. This is one employer that I unreservedly consider not going back to.

review_title: PhD Programme at Diabetes & Nutrition Dept
pros: KCL has a great name and will be good on your CV.
cons:
However, not every department is equal and the Dept for Diabetes and Nutrition is certainly one of the lower ones.
Barely any of the PIs has Grant money and they're all overworked. Generally, the mood between the academics was very low due to the lack of leadership from management.
Support systems for PhD students are quite scarce.

job_title: Head of Service in London, England
pros: Can be great for progression, lots of opportunity due to the size of the organisation. Also lots of training and professional development opportunities. Ambitious new strategy leading up to 2029.
cons: Different parts of the organisation have different cultures. Can be bureaucratic and slow to change. Strong sense of hierarchy can slow progress.

pros:
Top level research
Excellent colleagues
Good support for senior academics
Good locations in central London
Good links with hospitals to enable clinical research
cons:
Administration and HR are disastrous
Lack of support for post-docs or junior academics
Bad on gender equality...although improving
Salary is poor for the high expectations from Senior academics
Stability of jobs is doubtful, after rounds of redundancies
Criteria of performance have become entirely metric based

review_title: Great research intensive university. High standards and good research environment.
pros: High quality research environment, great colleagues. High calibre students. A serious focus on improving world rankings in both teaching and research.
cons: Teaching and teaching admin load too high. A two tier management system with division head and teaching head leads to competing interests and time demands.

review_title: Might be good for a career start, but not a lot of opportunity beyond that
pros:
- lots of opportunity to take courses 
- lots of gifted people that one could bounce ideas of
- lots of opportunity to find potential collaborators
cons:
- short contracts
- in the team I was in, it was predictable on who got contract extensions and it was not necessarily scientific merit that counted

pros: Excellent work-life balance and academic freedom; feel trusted by my team and line manager; always encouraged to learn and develop skills also outside direct field of specialisation.
cons: No clear route for promotion despite asking for clarification on this repeatedly; some issues with diversity (token women on panels, not enough work toward widening pool of existing experts).

pros: Smart people, many internal opportunities, open to change, pleasant environment, good salary, prestigious name, opportunities for professional growth and learning
cons: Long hours, doing things the "old way", very difficult to teach people new technologies and new approaches to work, difficult to communicate cross-college

review_title: Avoid the Denmark Hill campus - dreadful
pros: King’s is a fairly prestigious university, so looks good on CV; some of the *academic* staff are nice; students mostly ok; generally an easy 9-5 culture.
cons:
I’m still struggling to come to terms with just how dreadful working here as a temp was. You see, KCL relies heavily on temping staff, many of whom are kept on temp contracts for years despite doing a full-time, permanent role. This means that they can be ‘let go’ of quickly and with no questions asked. I spent about 2 months here, and despite picking up the very job quickly and getting good feedback from senior staff, I received a phone call one evening at 5.10 and told not to come in again. No explanation was given for this, and they then ignored my phone calls and emails. Though some of the academic staff here are quite nice, the administrative team were vile – gossipy, rude and unfriendly. For example, I was placed with a ‘colleague’ who made no secret of the fact she resented my presence for some reason, snapping at me whenever I asked for help or advice. She then began ignoring me when I said ‘good morning’ and ‘goodbye’, completely blanking me for weeks for no reason. The exceptions to this were when other staff members were present, when she spent some time badmouthing other staff behind their backs. This sort of behaviour seemed entirely normal for this office and though I was only there for 2 months I could really pick up on the level of tension and politics in this place and wasn’t too sorry to leave (though a day’s notice would have been nice). 


As for management – two-faced, spineless and useless, and they really couldn’t care about you as a person. Mine for instance repeatedly got my name wrong, and conveniently was 'working from home' on the day I was fired with no explanation. A real control freak – she could scarcely hide her irritation that my predecessor had created a to-do document before leaving, seemingly without her knowledge – she demanded that I email her a copy, then quizzed me on each item one-by-one in a highly patronising manner at our weekly catch-up meetings. Ironically I was working for the mental health studies team, and my placement coincided with KCL making a big huzzah about improving staff mental health and wellbeing. Utterly shameless hypocrites. 


As for the office itself, KCL has some good locations in central London, however it’s clear that the Denmark Hill campus is the poor relation. After years working in Central London I quite liked the peace and quiet, however the buildings themselves are hideous 70s time-warps desperately in need of renovation and decoration – think unwashed dishes left in sinks for weeks, stained carpets, 10 year old safety posters stuck up with yellowing sellotape etc. – a real dump. The exceptions to this are the reception and some of the ground floor areas visitors might see. Maybe KCL could take some of that money they’re spending on buying up central London property and spruce up the DH campus as frankly it’s an embarrassment. 


And the job itself – boring, tedious, dead-end - a living lesson in Parkinson’s Law. At KCL every possible admin process has its own separate IT system with separate login and getting anything done involves jumping through about 5 different hoops. For example, my phone didn’t work properly so I asked for new one – cue a month-long rigmarole being passed around 4-5 different departments, at the end of which I still didn’t have a new phone – in the end I just gave up. Very tedious - certainly not a place to develop a career or learn new skills.
